newsitem.title: USA: Sequel, Integralis, SRA develop email surveillance.
newsitem.headline: Sequel, Integralis, SRA develop email surveillance.

text.p: Three private companies, Sequel Technology, Integralis and SRA International, will announce Tuesday an application to help the financial community track e-mail messages.

The products, which are designed to comply with a new mandate by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for securing broker/customer electronic mail messages, are expected to be available on July 1 after testing.

"It will find things like when brokers are recommending outrageous valuations on stocks," said a spokesman of SRA International, adding it will also help firms screen for messages that prompt claims of harassment, for example.
SRA's natural language capabilities can be used to check incoming messages from customers and flag those involving complaints, for example, the SRA spokesman said.

"We're working with a couple of large brokerage houses in New York," the spokesman said, adding the three companies were not aware of each other until a customer put them together to help address the issue.
The companies expect to apply the technology to other industries, such as banking, law and health care, he said.

Sequel Technology CEO Stuart Rosove said in a statement prepared for the announcement that the financial markets may be the first industry recognizing the need for using surveillance to control legal liability risks.

The system, which combines Sequel's ability to log, report and manage Internet use with Integralis's e-mail content management software, can provide audit trails for identifying certain types of messages.
